image.altText: Leeroy stands grinning with his arms crossed, while Brett leans his elbow on a boat and laughs.

items.synopsis: Australian kids in out-of-home-care usually go through multiple placements and rarely get therapeutic support to deal with trauma. A new model of care that pays mental health experts to become full-time foster parents aims to change that.

image.altText: The US Capitol's domed building against a grey sky with a lone US flag flying.

items.synopsis: All eyes are on the US House of Representatives ahead of a vote on a bill to lift the $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling, while the ASX is set to open lower as investors weigh the possibility of a rate hike. Follow live.

title.children: US debt ceiling bill heads to a vote as risk of default looms, ASX to slip over rate hike concerns

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're still paying off your HECS-HELP debt, I have some bad news for you — your debt is going up today. That's because the loans are being indexed today at a rate of 7.1%. This happens every year to bring debts in line with inflation, but it's a sharp increase compared to years gone by. Last year, it was 3.9%, and the year before it was a 0.6% increase. Overall the change will affect more than 3 million debts. If you're wanting to know how much more you'll be paying on your HECS-HELP debt, you can find out with the calculator below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Happening today: HECS-HELP debts are going up

featuredLink.title: HECS-HELP loans are indexed today. Check how much your loan will increase with our calculator

children.content: If you're still paying off your HECS-HELP debt, I have some bad news for you — your debt is going up today.
That's because the loans are being indexed today at a rate of 7.1%.
This happens every year to bring debts in line with inflation, but it's a sharp increase compared to years gone by.
Last year, it was 3.9%, and the year before it was a 0.6% increase.
Overall the change will affect
more than 3 million debts
If you're wanting to know how much more you'll be paying on your HECS-HELP debt, you can find out with the calculator below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's stay overseas for a moment as the US debt ceiling vote approaches. It's no small feat for this bill to be making it through the House of Representatives today — Republicans control the house, and it's Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy that has been demanding spending cuts in exchange for an agreement to lift the debt ceiling. But just how narrow a path is the bill facing? Republicans control the House by a very narrow 222-213 majority, so the bill will need their support to pass. But the problem lies with the fact that some Republicans object to significant parts of the legislation, despite teased out negotiations between McCarthy and US President Joe Biden. Democrats also object to significant chunks of the legislation. It is expected the bill will pass, but if it doesn't, it will increase the risk of the US heading to default. If it does pass, the bill will still have to pass through the Senate, where the Democrats have a majority. If you're still unsure about what the deal with the US debt ceiling is, here's an explainer I pulled together a little while ago:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The US debt ceiling bill is facing a narrow path to victory

featuredLink.title: 'It's a really huge deal': Why the US debt ceiling crisis has implications for Australia

children.content: Let's stay overseas for a moment as the US debt ceiling vote approaches.

It's no small feat for this bill to be making it through the House of Representatives today — Republicans control the house, and it's Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy that has been demanding spending cuts in exchange for an agreement to lift the debt ceiling.
But just how narrow a path is the bill facing?
Republicans control the House by a
very
narrow 222-213 majority, so the bill will need their support to pass.
But the problem lies with the fact that some Republicans object to significant parts of the legislation, despite teased out negotiations between McCarthy and US President Joe Biden.
Democrats also object to significant chunks of the legislation.
It is expected the bill will pass, but if it doesn't, it will increase the risk of the US heading to default.
If it does pass, the bill will still have to pass through the Senate, where the Democrats have a majority.
If you're still unsure about what the deal with the US debt ceiling is, here's an explainer I pulled together a little while ago:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and a very happy first day of winter to you — it's Thursday, June 1 and you're reading the ABC's markets and business blog. Let's start overseas, where all eyes are on the US House of Representatives. They're sitting to decide the fate of the US debt ceiling bill that has been the subject of long, drawn out negotiations between US President Joe Biden and Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy as X-date edges closer. It's going to be a tight vote — and we can expect an outcome mid-morning here in Australia. In anticipation, Wall Street finished slightly lower, with labour data also weighing the possibility of a further US rate hike. Back home and the local share market is set to open lower as investors consider the possibility of higher interest rates, after monthly inflation jumped up more than economists were expecting to 6.8%. We saw the ASX fall yesterday in response to the data, but with the RBA's interest rate decision looming next Tuesday (it always comes around so quickly) they're now looking ahead to whether the central bank will pause, or potentially raise rates again. One thing that will be feeding into the RBA's decision making process next week is house prices, which have continued to strongly rebound. Let's get into it, shall we?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to slip as the US House of Representatives decide the fate of the debt ceiling

Thursday, June 1
and you're reading the ABC's markets and business blog.

US House of Representatives
. They're sitting to decide the

that has been the subject of long, drawn out negotiations between

and
Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy
as X-date edges closer.
It's going to be a tight vote — and we can expect an outcome
mid-morning here in Australia
In anticipation, Wall Street finished slightly lower, with labour data also weighing the possibility of a further US rate hike.

props.alt: Eight white men stand behind a podium with the US Capitol building in the background.

children.content: The debt ceiling bill will need the support of House Republicans if it's to pass.
(Reuters: Craig Hudson)
Back home and the local share market is set to open lower as investors consider the
possibility of higher interest rates
, after monthly inflation jumped up more than economists were expecting to 6.8%.

We saw the ASX fall yesterday in response to the data, but with the RBA's interest rate decision looming next Tuesday (it always comes around so quickly) they're now looking ahead to whether the central bank will pause, or potentially raise rates again.
One thing that will be feeding into the RBA's decision making process next week is
house prices, which have continued to strongly rebound
Let's get into it, shall we?
